summary.seg: According to the list of contents at the beginning of this manuscript, it once belonged to Ramsey Abbey, and had been donated to its treasury (properly 'armariolum', a small chest or cupboard that is found in sacristy of a church and intended for keeping vestments and other valuables safe) by one of the abbey's monks, brother Ralph of Olney (active c. 1267–85). This evidence of provenance is confirmed by multiple additions by late 13th- and early 14th-century hands that relate to events and daily life at Ramsey Abbey. Some of the excerpts on ff. 68r-69r bear a remarkable resemblance to the content appended to Cambridge, Corpus Christi College, MS 468 (see: ff. vii recto-x verso), another manuscript that has a Ramsey Abbey provenance. Brother Ralph of Olney himself is known to have served Abbot William of Godmanchester (abbot 1267-1285) as 'custos operum' - warden of the works - a position of some authority.

Various theological texts that had direct application in a monastic setting form the principal contents of the manuscript. We find a text on the institution of novices (ff. 5r-12v), a treatise on penance (ff. 13r-28v) and another one of cloistered life and its challenges (ff. 30r-51r). The compilation reveals also an interest in the past, with a text describing the legend of Charlemagne's alleged conquest of Spain (ff. 51v-64v), which is part of the French Chanson de geste tradition. The manuscript once contained more texts: the list of contents mentions ten others that are no longer to be found in the volume. Among these are a Rule of St Benedict, texts on virtues and vices, on the Ten Commandments, and the Seven Sacraments. A text called 'Donatus' likely refers to a grammar that was a popular text used to teach Latin to young students.

Several of the additions to the manuscript illustrate the multilingual culture of 13th-century England. While the main texts are written in Latin, the additions and accompanying material show the parallel existence of Anglo-Norman French and Middle English. There are prayers and a homily in Anglo-Norman French addressed to a religious community (f. 3r), and a brief note on the age of Virgin Mary (f. 71r), while Middle English is used for writing down the Lord's prayer and Hail Mary (f. 70v). The translation of texts between these languages is illustrated in the lower margin of f. 71r, where a line of Anglo-Norman is followed by the same line in Latin, and another line in Middle English is followed by a translation into Latin.

Tuija Ainonen
Project Cataloguer
Cambridge University Library

msContents.textLang: Latin, with few notes in Middle English and Anglo-Norman French

msItem.title: Miscellaneous notes
msItem.note: Added by various 13th-century hands.

msItem.title: Notes on events relating to Ramsey Abbey
msItem.incipit: anno domini mo cco xxiiijo in octabis sancte trinitatis ...
msItem.note: Notes on events on years 1224, 1266, 1271, 1276, and 1280, added in various hands.

msItem.title: Notes on the effect of fennel
msItem.incipit: 1v Effectus maratri. Visum clarificat. Auditum confortat ...

msItem.title: List of contents
msItem.rubric: Isti libri continentur in hoc uolumine quod quidem uolumen fr. R. de Olneya dedit Armariolo Ramesye cuius animam absoluat dominus Ihesus Christus. Amen
msItem.note:
The list of contents includes fourteen items, ten of which are missing (starred in the following):
Doctrinale uel disciplinale magistri Hugonis de sancto Victore
*De quatuor uirtutibus cardinalibus
*Formula uite monachorum secundum beatum Bernardum edita
*Regula sancti Benedicti
*Bernardus de precepto et dispensacione
*Meditaciones eiusdem
*De vii mortalibus peccatis et eorum speciebus
Liber Aurelii Augustini de uera penitencia
Tractatus de xii abusionibus domini Hugonis de folieto
Epistola Turpini Archiepiscopi Remensis ad Leoprandum decanum aquisgranensis
*Decem precepta decalogi
*Septem sacramenta
*Templum domini a magistro R. cognomento Grosseteste compilatum
*Donatus

msItem.title: A list of towns
msItem.rubric: Hec uia tendit a mari usque Lugdunum
msItem.incipit: Whitsond Bologne Mustroyl Mantenoy ...
msItem.note: A list of the towns on the way "a mari usque Lugdunum" and "per pontem uersus paris".

msItem.title: Riddle
msItem.incipit:
Hic pendent situle gemine quarum uice uersa
Retrogradum facit una gradum redit altera mersa
msItem.note: The same riddle can be found in two other 13th-century manuscripts, one now in Auxerre, Bibliothèque municipale, 007, f. 2r and the other, in a manuscript from Bayeux, France c. 1268-1274, now Oxford, Bodleian Library, MS. Laud. misc. 644 f. 123vb (after item 10 in the Quarto Catalogue entry).

msItem.title: Note
msItem.note: In a large hand, the names of "Gregorius, Augustinus, Cassiodorus, Origenes, Ambrosius, Ieronimus, Beda, Isidore" and the line: "Interius scripta latitare putetis eorum. Externis picta calamo sunt nomina quorum."

msItem.title: Bidding prayers
msItem.incipit: 3r Prium pur la pes de seinte eglise et pur la pes de la tere...
msItem.note: Ten brief petitions in prose. Only known survivors of Anglo-Norman bidding prayers, and one of the earliest versions in French to survive.

msItem.title: Homily
msItem.incipit: 3r Deu nus doint isi parler ke sauvete soit a nos almes ...
msItem.note: Addessed to a religious community, probably monks of Ramsey Abbey, closing with absolution.
Short note on qualifications of an abbot. Most of f. 4r and all of f. 4v blank.

msItem.title: De Institutione Nouitiorum
msItem.author: Hugh of St Victor
msItem.rubric: 5r Incipit doctrinale uel disciplinale magistri Hugonis de Victore
msItem.incipit: 5r Quia largiente deo
msItem.note: Imperfec

listBibl.bibl: Goy, Die Überlieferung der Werke Hugos von St. Viktor pp. 340–67 (p. 345, item 27)

msItem.title: De uera et falsa poenitentia
msItem.author: pseudo-Augustine
msItem.rubric: 13r Liber Aurelii Augustini de uera et falsa penitencia
msItem.incipit: 13r Quantum sit appetenda
msItem.finalRubric: 28v Aureli Augustini doctoris eximii de uera penitencia liber explicit
msItem.note: f. 29 blank.

msItem.title: Verses and a commentary

msItem.incipit: Hic Augustinus mihi se mihi me mihi Christum
Villa bones uxor cenam clausere vocatis
In magnitudine enim magnanimitas quemadmodum
msItem.note: Quote from Aquinas's Commentary on Aristotle, Ethics, Bk. 4 Lectio 8.738, followed by a commentary.
Three additions written by two different late 13th- and 14th-century hands in previously blank space; f. 29r-v ruled but blank.

msItem.title: De xii abusionibus claustri
msItem.author: Hugh of Fouilloy
msItem.note: Part of Hugh's work De claustro anime.

msItem.title: Prologue
msItem.incipit: 30r Locuturus karissime

msItem.title: De claustro animae (chapers 12-23)
msItem.rubric: 30r Incipit tractatus de xii abusiuis dompni hugonis de folieto prioris canonicorum sancti laurencii in pago ambianensi. Prima abusio. prelatus negligens
msItem.incipit: 30v Sunt quidam qui sciunt

msItem.title: Moral story
msItem.incipit: 51r Quidam filius diuitis
msItem.note: A paragraph added by a late 13th-century hand about a rich man's son wishing to enter a monastery.

msItem.title: Historia Karoli Magni et Rotholandi
msItem.author: pseudo-Turpin
msItem.rubric: 51v Incipit epistola turpini archiepiscopi Remensis ad leoprandum decanum aquisgranensem
msItem.incipit: 51v Turpinus dei gratia
msItem.note: Ends imperfect in chapter 19. Part of the D recension of the text, and a direct copy of BnF, Latin 14703 (Meredith-Jones, p. 17).

listBibl.bibl: C. Meredith-Jones, Historia Karoli Magni et Rotholandi: ou, Chronique du Pseudo-Turpin (Paris 1936, repr. Genève 1972)

msItem.title: Chronica
msItem.author: Walterus Gisburnensis
msItem.incipit: 65r quod ubi Christus pro se et petro
msItem.note: Exerpts from Chronica, book 3 p. 256-59 and book 4 p. 275 (years 1307-1308); added with a 14th-century cursive hand.

listBibl.bibl: Rothwell, Harry (ed.), The chronicle of Walter of Guisborough: previously edited as the chronicle of Walter of Hemingford or Hemingburgh, Royal Historical Society, Camden Society, Camden third series 89 (London, 1957).

msItem.title: Miscellany of prognostics, verses, hymns, quotes and charters
Charter
msItem.incipit: 66v Willelmi dei gratia Abbas Ramesye
msItem.explicit: 66v anno domini mo cco lxxx iio
msItem.note: A charter of William of Godmanchester (abbot of Ramsey Abbey 1267-1285), appointing bailiffs of the manor of Gravenhurst in 1282.
Upper margin includes few lines of verse in Latin; f. 66r blank.

msItem.title: Prognostics
msItem.incipit: 67r Signum quod ostendit dominus hesdre prophete ut ostenderet filiis hominum
msItem.note: Appears also in Cambridge, Corpus Christi College, MS 468, f. vii recto.
A brief excerpt (Vitae Patrum 38) added in the empty space in the column.

msItem.title: Verses
msItem.note:
Upper margin includes a trimmed Latin distich and English equivalent:
I am Rose wo is me ∙ sutere þat i suete þe
I wacs þat weylawey. cherles hand me þristet ay.

msItem.title: Charter
msItem.rubric: 67v Carta pie memorie Hugonis abbatis Ramesey cognom' de Sulegraue
msItem.incipit: 67v Vniuersis Christi fidelibus presens scriptum
msItem.note: A charter of Hugh of Sulgrave (abbot of Ramsey Abbey 1254-1267).

msItem.title: Verses on names of trees
msItem.incipit: 68r Fraxinus et corulus planus et salix
msItem.note: Appears also in Cambridge, Corpus Christi College, MS 468, f. vii verso.

msItem.title: Verses on avarice and on corruption
msItem.author: Walter of Châtillon
msItem.rubric: 68r Quod nummus ubique regnat et imperat.
msItem.incipit: 68r Captiuata largitas longe relegatur
msItem.explicit: 68r Frustra gemens uidua preces fundit hodie
msItem.note: Bottom of the leaf cut.
Appears also in Cambridge, Corpus Christi College, MS 468, f. vii verso

listBibl.bibl: Walter of Châtillon. (2013). The shorter poems: Christmas hymns, love lyrics, and moral-satirical verse. D. A. Traill (Ed.). (Oxford Medieval Texts). J. W. Binns, D. d'Avray, M. S. Kempshall, & R. C. Love (Eds.) Oxford: Oxford University Press. Oxford Scholarly Editions Online (2019). doi:10.1093/actrade/9780199297399.book.1. Poems 38 and 39 (MS not cited).

msItem.title: Prophecy
msItem.incipit: 68v Li plus beaus a Martheus etc.
msItem.note: Prophecy of deaths of the 4 sons of Henry II.

msItem.title: Prognostics of thunder
msItem.incipit: 68v Accedens quicunque cupis cognoscere uerba
msItem.explicit: 69r Indicium primum non feret immo sequens
msItem.note: Appears also in Cambridge, Corpus Christi College, MS 468, ff. viii recto- x recto
On 69r are added a number of verses and notes, for example notes on quantities of flour etc. received in the year; and a note on the symbolism of pastoral staff.

msItem.title: Hymn for Nativity
msItem.incipit: 69v Ortum floris concinat laus oris uas dulcoris miri flos odoris
msItem.note: With 4 line stave

f. 69v: added note in the lower margin: In vento minime pluuia niue sole sedere
possumus in claustro nec scribere neque studere.

msItem.title: Historical and other notes
msItem.note: 1275. Deed of William (de Gomecestre?) appointing Hugo de Banham proctor at Rome. Vig. S. Barthol.
Declensions of cherub and seraph; derivation of 'Adam' from Anathole, dysis, Arthos, mesimbrios
1277. Archbishop Robert de Chuluartby (Kilwardby) visited the abbey.

msItem.title: Lord's prayer
msItem.incipit: Hure fader

msItem.title: Hail Mary
msItem.incipit: 70v Heyl Marie of grace

msItem.title: Hymn to Virgin Mary
msItem.incipit: 70v O cunctis excelsior angelorum choris
msItem.note: On upper and lower margin, moral and memorial verses

listBibl.bibl: Analecta Hymnica (1893) 15, 112 (edited from this and other copies).

msItem.incipit:
Nullam causidico reor esse fidem neque dico
Hosti pro modico fit amicus et hostis amico
Nexus ovem geminam per spinam traxit equinam
Hospitis in mensa uultum non fercula pensa

listBibl.bibl: Werner, Lateinische Sprichwörter und Sinnsprüche des Mittelalters (Heidelberg 1912) p. 37 h41.

msItem.incipit: Si dare vis suspende morani da fonte sereno
Corpore castus munere largus corde fidelis

Gustu laboraui subito casu laboraui
surge laboraui bonus est ueniens laboraui
Quem mea culpa ligat

listBibl.bibl: Werner, Lateinische Sprichwörter und Sinnsprüche des Mittelalters (Heidelberg 1912) p. 76 q51.

msItem.incipit: Virgo fides fidis est resonat fidis in citharando
Rumor de ueteri faciet uentura timeri

listBibl.bibl: Werner, Lateinische Sprichwörter und Sinnsprüche des Mittelalters (Heidelberg 1912) p. 86 r76.

msItem.incipit:
Perdidit in mense falco tam feruidus ense
Omnie sub seuo quicquid quesiuit ab euo

msItem.title: Riddle
msItem.incipit:
Edificor saxis me sustinet in pede marmor
'p' si dematur colo pascua cornibus armor
sillaba si bina dematur fio metallum
'e' si dematur troianum destruo bellum.

msItem.title: Recipe against fever
msItem.incipit: Contra febres

msItem.title: Antiphons for commemoration and a prayer of St Edmund
msItem.incipit: Custodi nos in noctibus Edmundi
Mane nobicum maneas
Confessoris tui atque pontificis domine

msItem.title: Graecismus (excerpt cap. 17.79-85)
msItem.author: Evrard de Béthune
msItem.incipit: Alloquitur qui me compellit uoce loquendo

listBibl.bibl: Eberhard von Bethune, Graecismus. Herausgegeben von Johannes Wrobel. (Uratislauiae 1887, Repr. Georg Olms Verlag 1987).

msItem.incipit:
Nostre dame seinte marie uesqui
xiiii aunz devant le incarnacium
e pus fu nostre seignur od lui xxxiii
anz. e pus su ele en la garde sem
Ian. xvi e si fu tut sun age
en ceste aunz.
msItem.note: Not in Dean and Boulton.

msItem.title: Alexandreis (excerpt 8.412-15)
msItem.author: Walter of Châtillon
msItem.incipit: Esse sui iuris hominem sua seque tueri

msItem.title: Historical and other notes
msItem.note: 1240 16 Kal. Dec. Death of St Edmund.
1246 5 Id. Jun. Translatio of St Edmund. Indulgence.

msItem.textLang: Anglo-Norman French, Middle English and Latin
msItem.title: Trilingual translation of maxims
msItem.incipit:
Es peyse. houme le peise. peyse lui ke le peyse.
ponderat es. homo librat. eum piget. es trutinare
þe belle ringeth. þe folch wepeth. men byrieth þe man. þe prest biseketh
es sonat vulgus plorat uir humatur
msItem.note: Not in Dean and Boulton.

foliation.note: Numbering in pencil in the upper right-hand corner of the rectos, coinciding with foliation in ink (see below).
Numbering in ink in the lower right-hand corner of the rectos.

collation.p:
10 quires of varied composition, with losses to content.
Quire 12 (ff. 1-2)
Quire 22 (ff. 3-4)
Quire 310-2 (ff. 5-12: 9th and 10th leaves, after f. 12, missing. The stub of the missing leaves have been misbound, appearing between ff. 6 and 7, rather than ff. 12 and 13)
Quire 410 (ff. 13-22)
Quire 58-1 (ff. 23-29: 8th leaf, after f. 29, missing)
Quire 68 (ff. 30-37)
Quire 78 (ff. 38-45)
Quire 88 (ff. 46-53)
Quire 912-1 (ff. 54-64: 12th leaf, after f. 64, excised)
Quire 102 (ff. 65-66)
Quire 114+1 (ff. 67-71: 5th leaf, f. 71, a singleton).
collation.note: Henry Bradshaw interpreted quires 10 and 11 to be one quire of 4 sheets with the 3rd leaf (after f. 66v) gone (incorrectly).

catchwords.seg: Two catchwords survive, one on f. 37v, the other on f. 53r indicates loss of text.

layout.seg: Mainly double columns with 27 lines to the page, ruled in ink. Folios 1v-4r and 65r-66v ruled and written in single columns; f. 67v ruled in double columns but written in single column; ff. 69v-70r written in single columns with red ink ruling for the notation; ff. 70v-71r unruled. Written above the top line.

handNote.p: Various 13th- and 14th-century cursive hands added texts on ff. 1v-4v and 65r-71r.

decoNote.p: Folios 5-64: pen-flourished initials in red and blue.
Folios 5-64: plain initials alternating in red and blue.

note.p: Quire signatures added in pencil by Mr Bradshaw on lower corner of first folio of each quire, starting on f. 5: A, f. 13r: 2A, f. 23: 2B, f. 30: 3A, f. 38: 3B, f. 46r: 3C, f. 54r: 3D, f. 65: 4A.

binding.p: 17th-century paper cover over couched-laminate boards. Brown leather spine with a general title tooled in gold: Tracts M.S. All three edges coloured in blue.
Binding height: 205 mm, width: 55 mm, depth: 25 mm.

provenance.p: f. 2r: Ramsey Abbey: Given to the treasury (armariolo) of Ramsey Abbey by brother Ralph de Olneya, inscribed rubric for the list of contents, Isti libri continentur in hoc uolumine quod quidem uolumen frater R. de Olneya dedit Armariolo Ramesye.
f. i recto: possibly Samuel Clarke Clarke, Samuel, 1599-1682 : ownership inscription, perhaps date of acquisition: Sam Clarke. Maij 17, 1658.

John Moore (1646-1714), bishop of Ely Moore, John, 1646-1714 : no. 881 in the handwritten supplementary list of Moore's manuscripts, now MS Oo.7.50.2, compiled by Thomas Tanner (1674-1735) Tanner, Thomas, 1674-1735 after the publication of Bernard, Catalogi librorum manuscriptorum Angliæ et Hiberniæ (c. 1697).

history.acquisition: Presented to the University Library in 1715 by George I George I, King of Great Britain, 1660-1727 : donation bookplate engraved by John Pine Pine, John, 1690-1756 in 1736 on upper inside cover.

recordHist.source: This catalogue entry draws on an unpublished description of the manuscript composed between 1926 and 1930 by M.R. James James, M.R. (Montague Rhodes), 1862-1936, now held in the University Archives (UA ULIB 7/3/74).

availability.p: Entry to read in the Library is permitted only on presentation of a valid reader's card. For information on eligibility and admissions procedures, see Joining the Library). For further information on the availability of the manuscript, please contact the Manuscripts Reading Room.
